Award.AwardTitle: Conference proposal: International Symposium on High-Order Methods for Computational Fluid Dynamics (San Diego, CA, July 26-30, 2015)

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The symposium will be attended by both prominent and young scientists in computational mathematics and computational fluid dynamics from around the world, who will be discussing future directions of research and research challenges that, if addressed rigorously, would have a strong impact in technology. Better computational modeling of fluid dynamics in complicated geometries can lead to improved understanding of a number of engineering problems in aerospace and naval applications, biomedical applications, wind energy production and energy conservation, etc.

The proposal seeks funds to partially cover travel expenses of speakers and student participants to the conference entitled, "2015 International Symposium on High-Order Methods for Computational Fluid Dynamics", to be held in San Diego, CA, during July 26-30, 2015. This international symposium emphasizes the fundamental development of high-order computational mathematics methods for solving fluid problems with complex geometry. The meeting will emphasize the development of methods for robust and accurate methods for shock capturing; efficient methods for turbulence modeling (Large Eddy Simulations and Reynolds Averaged Navier-Stokes simulations); high-order computation mesh generation with curved elements and resolving wall flow physics; moving and deforming grids to enable high-fidelity simulation of fluid-structure interaction; implementing high-order methods using more efficient computer architectures and GPU systems; and using high-order methods for predicting new flow physics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
An international symposium on high-order CFD methods was successfully held in July 2015 in conjunction with the 14th US National Congress on Computational Mechanics held in San Diego, California. This symposium features 21 presentations including 3 keynote lectures. Total 40 participants attended this symposium. The presenters came from US, Germany, Japan, Canada, France, Spain, China, and Italy and include two female researchers.  The sympsium enabled graduate students, postdocs, and professors to have extensive interaction over three days during the conference held in San Diego. A majority part of this NSF award has been used to support the registration fee for speakers to attend this symposium. The remaining part was used to support student travel and lodging. Twenty-three researchers submitted technical manuscripts for the consideration by the Computers & Fluids journal. A rigorous two-round reviews were given by invited researchers in this specialized area. A special issue on high-order CFD methods featuring 20 final technical articles has been published in November 2016 by the Computers & Fluids (an international journal) disseminating in the worldwide community of high-order CFD methods. This special issue is also dedicated to the 60th birthday of Professor David A. Kopriva, a pioneer and creative researcher in the area of high-order CFD methods.
